verses.text: After this, the Moabites and Ammonites, and with them some of the Meunites, came against Jehoshaphat for battle.
verses.comment: Modern 'Meunites' translates 'Meunim', a people from Edom region.

verses.text: Some men came and told Jehoshaphat, "A great multitude is coming against you from beyond the sea, from Edom. They are already at Hazazon-tamar (that is, En-gedi)."
verses.comment: Hazazon-tamar is another name for En-gedi, on the west shore of the Dead Sea.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was afraid and set his face to seek the LORD, and he called for a fast throughout all Judah.
verses.comment: The act of seeking God by proclamation of fasting emphasises communal repentance.

verses.text: Judah gathered to seek help from the LORD; they came from all the cities of Judah to seek the LORD.
verses.comment: Literal translation preserves repetition of 'seek the LORD' for emphasis.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat stood in the assembly of Judah and Jerusalem, in the house of the LORD, before the new court,
verses.comment: The 'new court' refers to an area of the Temple recently restored.

verses.text: and he said, "O LORD, God of our ancestors, are you not God in heaven? You rule over all kingdoms of the nations. In your hand are power and might, and no one can withstand you.
verses.comment: Modern phrasing for 'thou art not God', preserving original address.

verses.text: "Did you not, our God, drive out the inhabitants of this land before your people Israel, and give it forever to the descendants of Abraham, your friend?
verses.comment: Preserved 'your friend' for Abraham, as in original.

verses.text: They have lived in it and have built for you a sanctuary in it for your name, saying,
verses.comment: Hebrew emphasises 'for your name'—maintained here.

verses.text: "If disaster comes upon us, whether sword, judgment, pestilence, or famine, we will stand before this house and before you—for your name is in this house—and cry out to you in our trouble, and you will hear and save.
verses.comment: Translation retains conditional phrasing and parallel threats.

verses.text: "And now, here are the men of Ammon, Moab, and Mount Seir, whom you would not let Israel invade when they came from Egypt, but they turned aside from them and did not destroy them.
verses.comment: Preserved the explanation of why those nations were spared.

verses.text: See how they repay us by coming to drive us out of your possession, which you gave us to inherit.
verses.comment: Maintains clarity between 'Your possession' and Israel's inheritance.

verses.text: O our God, will you not judge them? For we are powerless against this great multitude that is coming against us. We do not know what to do, but our eyes are on you."
verses.comment: Explicit statement of dependence reflects the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: All Judah stood before the LORD, with their little ones, their wives, and their children.
verses.comment: Emphasises the inclusion of all people, as in original.

verses.text: Then the Spirit of the LORD came upon Jahaziel the son of Zechariah, son of Benaiah, son of Jeiel, son of Mattaniah, a Levite of the sons of Asaph, in the midst of the assembly.
verses.comment: Genealogical line from Asaph with Levite identity is maintained.

verses.text: He said, "Listen, all Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem, and King Jehoshaphat: Thus says the LORD to you, ‘Do not be afraid or discouraged because of this great multitude, for the battle is not yours, but God’s.’
verses.comment: Direct speech and encouragement closely matches Hebrew structure.

verses.text: "Tomorrow, go down against them. See, they will come up by the ascent of Ziz, and you will find them at the end of the valley, before the wilderness of Jeruel.
verses.comment: ‘Ascent of Ziz’ and ‘wilderness of Jeruel’ are geographical notes; preserved in translation.

verses.text: "You will not need to fight in this battle. Stand firm, hold your position, and see the deliverance of the LORD on your behalf, O Judah and Jerusalem.' Do not be afraid or discouraged. Tomorrow, go out against them, and the LORD will be with you."
verses.comment: Retains parallel structure and repetition for emphasis.

verses.text: Then Jehoshaphat bowed his face to the ground, and all Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem fell down before the LORD, worshipping the LORD.
verses.comment: Preserved action verbs and subject order.

verses.text: The Levites, from the sons of the Kohathites and the sons of the Korahites, stood up to praise the LORD, the God of Israel, with a very loud voice.
verses.comment: Levite families specified, reflecting Temple service roles.

verses.text: They rose early in the morning and went out into the wilderness of Tekoa. As they went out, Jehoshaphat stood and said, "Hear me, Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem! Believe in the LORD your God, and you will be established; believe his prophets and you will succeed."
verses.comment: Faith in both God's power and prophetic word is emphasised.

verses.text: When he had consulted with the people, he appointed those who would sing to the LORD and praise him in holy attire, as they went out before the army, saying, "Give thanks to the LORD, for his steadfast love endures forever."
verses.comment: "Holy attire" reflects ‘holy garments’ or ‘holy splendor.’

verses.text: As they began to sing and praise, the LORD set ambushes against the men of Ammon, Moab, and Mount Seir, who had come against Judah, and they were defeated.
verses.comment: Ambushes could include confusion or supernatural intervention—left ambiguous as original.

verses.text: For the men of Ammon and Moab rose against the inhabitants of Mount Seir to destroy and annihilate them. After they had made an end of the inhabitants of Seir, they all helped to destroy one another.
verses.comment: Descriptions of inner conflict among the enemy reflect the Hebrew verbs.

verses.text: When Judah came to the watchtower of the wilderness, they looked toward the multitude and saw only dead bodies lying on the ground; no one had escaped.
verses.comment: "Watchtower" preserves the geographical marker from the text.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat and his people came to take the spoil from them. They found among them an abundance of goods, clothing, and valuable items, which they took for themselves, more than they could carry. They were three days in taking the spoil, because there was so much.
verses.comment: Specifics of plunder: ‘goods, clothing, valuable items’—all from Hebrew.

verses.text: On the fourth day they assembled in the Valley of Beracah, for there they blessed the LORD. That is why it is called the Valley of Beracah to this day.
verses.comment: ‘Beracah’ means ‘blessing’—maintained for explanation.

verses.text: Then they returned, all the men of Judah and Jerusalem, with Jehoshaphat at their head, joyfully returning to Jerusalem, for the LORD had given them joy over their enemies.
verses.comment: Retains the concept of God giving joy as victory celebration.

verses.text: They came to Jerusalem with harps, lyres, and trumpets, to the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Liturgical instruments are specified as per Hebrew.

verses.text: The fear of God came on all the kingdoms of the countries when they heard that the LORD had fought against the enemies of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Fear of God’ is preserved as per original idiom.

verses.text: So the kingdom of Jehoshaphat was quiet, for God gave him peace all around.
verses.comment: ‘Peace all around’ is a Hebrew idiom for rest from enemies.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat reigned over Judah. He was thirty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned twenty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Azubah, the daughter of Shilhi.
verses.comment: Genealogical details and age preserved from source.

verses.text: He walked in the way of his father Asa and did not turn aside from it, doing what was right in the eyes of the LORD.
verses.comment: Retained classic biblical phrase ‘right in the eyes of the LORD.’

verses.text: Nevertheless, the high places were not removed; the people still had not set their hearts to the God of their ancestors.
verses.comment: Clarified that 'high places' refer to unauthorized worship sites.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat, from beginning to end, are written in the chronicles of Jehu the son of Hanani, which are recorded in the book of the kings of Israel.
verses.comment: Clarifies sources documenting Jehoshaphat’s reign.

verses.text: After this Jehoshaphat king of Judah joined with Ahaziah king of Israel, who acted wickedly.
verses.comment: Preserved negative moral evaluation of Ahaziah.

verses.text: He joined him in making ships to go to Tarshish, and they built the ships at Ezion-geber.
verses.comment: ‘Tarshish’ preserved, believed to refer to a location for trade, possibly Spain.

verses.text: Then Eliezer the son of Dodavahu of Mareshah prophesied against Jehoshaphat, saying, "Because you have joined Ahaziah, the LORD will destroy what you have made." The ships were wrecked and were not able to go to Tarshish.
verses.comment: Explicit link between disobedience and consequence. ‘Wrecked’ matches original verb meaning ‘broken.’
